intro: Tritheca pentandra, commonly known as the five-lobed sandverbena, is a flowering plant native to parts of South America. It belongs to the family Geraniaceae and is characterized by its distinctive five-lobed leaves and showy, pinkish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or well-drained soils, often in coastal or arid environments. It produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous tiny seeds, facilitating its dispersal by wind. Tritheca pentandra is valued for its ornamental appeal and its role in supporting local biodiversity.
